summary: This document discusses the authorization of a Power of Attorney for Jeffrey Epstein, allowing designated agents to manage his brokerage and retirement accounts with Deutsche Bank Securities Inc. It outlines the responsibilities of the agents and the limitations of their authority, as well as the necessary approvals for certain actions. The correspondence also highlights issues related to the notarization of signatures and the need for exceptions in the handling of Epstein's accounts.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein is mentioned as the client who has transferred significant funds into his accounts and is seeking to establish a Power of Attorney.

persons.name: Zbynek Kozelsky
persons.context: Zbynek Kozelsky is involved in the correspondence regarding the Power of Attorney and is part of the Markets Coverage Group at Deutsche Bank.

persons.name: Vahe Stepanian
persons.context: Vahe Stepanian is mentioned as part of the correspondence discussing the Power of Attorney for Epstein's accounts.

persons.name: Fran Wickman
persons.context: Fran Wickman is involved in the discussions about the Power of Attorney and the necessary approvals for Epstein's accounts.

persons.name: Jean Anne Brennan
persons.context: Jean Anne Brennan is appointed as an agent in the Power of Attorney for Epstein and is mentioned in relation to notarization issues.

persons.name: Harry I. Beller
persons.context: Harry I. Beller is mentioned as the notary public who acknowledges the signatures on the Power of Attorney document.

connections.description: Zbynek Kozelsky is involved in managing Epstein's accounts as part of Deutsche Bank.
Vahe Stepanian is part of the team handling Epstein's financial matters.
Fran Wickman is involved in the discussions regarding Epstein's Power of Attorney.
Jean Anne Brennan is appointed as an agent in Epstein's Power of Attorney.
Harry I. Beller notarizes the signatures of Jean Anne Brennan as part of the Power of Attorney process.

keyFacts: The document outlines a Power of Attorney for Jeffrey Epstein, allowing designated agents to manage his accounts.
It specifies that the agents must act in the best interest of the Principal (Epstein) and keep records of transactions.
The document highlights the need for notarization of signatures and the potential issues arising from agents notarizing their own signatures.
There are discussions about exceptions needed for the handling of Epstein's accounts due to the nature of the Power of Attorney.
The correspondence indicates that Epstein has transferred over $120 million into his accounts with Deutsche Bank.
